Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation in the National Geoscience Workforce: The National Association of Black Geoscientists Technical Conference 2014
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide support to defray expenses of student participants attending the 33rd Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG), September 17-20 2014, at the Washington State University campus on the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, Richland, WA. The NABG conference theme will be "Environmental Ideas for the Future", where "Environmental Ideas" might refer to the ecological environment, the economic environment, or the social environment, as well as traditional and non-traditional energy resources, all of which are undergoing unprecedented changes at this time. The primary goal of NABG is to mentor and advise students from under-represented backgrounds pursuing BS, MS, and PhD degrees in scientific, technical, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines, providing a competent and diverse workforce fulfilling critical national needs for the 21st Century. Professional members serve as role models to participating students, and engage in a number of mentoring activities including constructive criticism of student research projects, career counseling, guidance related to professional behavior and academic advising. The meeting serves as an opportunity for academic institutions, government agencies, and the energy/environmental industry to recruit students from underrepresented groups to STEM disciplines and employment in the national geosciences workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided participant support from the National Science Foundation to defray expenses of 72 students attending the Annual Technical Conference of the National Association of Black Geoscientists (NABG), 17 - 20 September 2014 in Richland, Washington and 9 - 12 September 2015 in Houston, TX. These were 33rd and 34th years for the conference and NABG is a leading professional organization promoting development of greater diversity within the national geosciences workforce, particularly within the energy and environmental industries, both areas of critical national need. The conferences provided forums where students-of-color highlighted their scientific and academic achievements in geosciences research through oral/poster presentations and interaction with practicing professionals. Both oral and poster presentations were presented by all participating students, and these presentations were critically evaluated by the professional membership of NABG during the conference. Professional members of NABG served as role models to participating students. Professional members also engaged in a number of mentoring activities including 1) constructive criticism of student research projects, 2) career counseling, 3) guidance related to professional behavior and etiquette at professional conferences, 4) academic advising, and 5) friendship. The meetings served as an opportunity for academic institutions to recruit students from underrepresented groups for advanced study in geosciences, as well as for government agencies and the energy/environmental industry to recruit minority students for internships and permanent employment. The academic-government-private sector partnership represented by professional participants at the conference has been an effective means of expanding opportunities for students-of-color in the national geosciences workforce and strengthens professional connections between academia, government, and industry.
